ranked_diseases.explanation: Perfect match with all key features: elevated 3-hydroxyglutaric acid, glutaric aciduria, elevated glutarylcarnitine, macrocephaly, subdural hemorrhage, cerebral atrophy, and developmental regression. All three reference cases with identical diagnoses share these same features.

Can present with glutaric aciduria and developmental issues, but typically has multiple acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency with different metabolic profile, hypoglycemia, and metabolic acidosis not mentioned in this case.
Rare variant with glutaric aciduria but usually without neurological symptoms. The presence of cerebral atrophy, macrocephaly, and developmental regression makes this less likely than type I.
Features elevated 3-hydroxyglutaric acid but typically without the full constellation of symptoms seen here including subdural hemorrhage and macrocephaly characteristic of GA-I.
Can present with developmental regression and cerebral atrophy in early childhood, but lacks the specific organic aciduria pattern and macrocephaly seen in this patient.
